body.header: Many of the ideas in the composition that you read in the last exercise can be expressed in different ways. Here are some of the ideas from the composition and a few extra ones. Complete the sentences by choosing the best linking word or phrase for each gap (...).

ol.li:
State-owned museums generally suffer from rising costs. ..., many are reluctant to introduce admission charges.
Whereas
However
Although
In spite of

... admission fees mean that a country's national heritage is only available to those who can afford to pay for it, free entrance makes it accessible to everyone.
While
However
In spite of
Despite

... the fact that many people make a special trip to visit free museums, a lot of people visit them on impulse.
While
However
Despite
Although

Entrance fees mean that museums are under pressure to entertain the public, ... free admission and state funding allow a museum to be more serious.
though
although
in spite of
whereas

... museums are popular attractions, they do not always receive sufficient funds.
Although
However
Despite

Museums try to maximise the number of visitors ... this leads to overcrowding at times.
whereas

Museums should be free for children and students. ..., adults should pay an admission fee.

Some governments regard museums as part of the education system. ..., for many visitors visiting them is first and foremost a leisure activity
Despite

... the increasing popularity of museums, taxpayers are generally unwilling to have their money spent on them.
Nevertheless

Some museums reflect mainstream culture, ... others are very specialist.
even though

section.p: 1. 'Whereas' and 'Although' join two clauses together, but this sentence only has one clause. 'In spite of' is always followed by a gerund or a noun.
2. 'However' can't be used to connect two clauses in this way. 'In spite of' and 'Despite' are always followed by a gerund or a noun.

p.font: 3. a, d: Notice the words 'the fact that' after the gap.
b: 'However' can't be used to connect two clauses in this way.

section.p: 4. What's missing here is a connector that shows contrast rather than concession.

p.font: 5. b: 'However' can't be used to connect two clauses in this way.
c: 'Despite' needs to be followed by a noun, a gerund or the phrase 'the fact that'.
d: 'Nevertheless' is used in the same way as 'However'. It can't be used to connect two clauses in this way.
6. a: 'Whereas' is used to show contrast rather than concession.
c, d: 'In spite of' and 'Despite' need to be followed by a noun, a gerund or the phrase 'the fact that'.
7. b, d: 'However' and 'Whereas' are used to connect two clauses together, but this sentence only has one clause. Notice the full stop after the word 'students'.
c: 'Despite' needs to be followed by a noun, a gerund or the phrase 'the fact that'.
8. a: 'Despite' needs to be followed by a noun, a gerund or the phrase 'the fact that'.
b, d: 'Although' and 'Whereas' are used to connect two clauses together, but this sentence only has one clause. Notice the full stop after the word 'system'.
9. a: 'Nevertheless' is used in the same way as 'However'. It can't be used to connect two clauses in this way.
b: 'Although' has to be followed by a subject + verb clause: although museums are popular...
d: 'while' has to be followed by a subject + verb clause: while museums are popular...
10. a: The missing connector is one which shows contrast rather than concession.
c: 'In spite of' and 'Despite' need to be followed by a noun, a gerund or the phrase 'the fact that'.

section.p: Choosing the correct linking word or phrases depends partly on the meaning of the sentence and partly on the grammar of the sentence. You should pay careful attention to both.
